I really did want to hit the hair harder but was advised to simplify it for the overall impact of the values and lighting. I had the curls done in the early stages but at the end went over them with a big brush And it made sense. Maybe in different context I would add more detail but for this piece the focus really needed to be on just the face, I simplified the ear an even the neck structure to make it happen
They hold the linseed oil and turpentine :p

I've only been here two weeks. Taking a summer portrait course. Class was $3200. Its amazing though. It is everything I dreamed of learning. I've been painting awhile and have never had such a great foundation for materials and process. Worth every penny. The studio is open to me24/7 and I am taking full advantage. Basically do a painting a day outside of class. Class is3 hours every day.
Florence academy of art. I don't think I could have made a better choice
:) thank you! It was a tough process. First time doing something like this.

IDAP of a friend
Just finished my first painting in Florence, Italy
Love. 24"x30. Oil on canvas.

WRITING.TEXT:
Foggy morning was about two nights, I cranked it out fairly quickly because I understood the values exactly how I wanted them and because of the limited color palette.
Warmth in winter was a transformation over time.. first it was just the building in cool greys and depressing moods, I went back in and added the flaming windows, textures and the person to lifen it up. probably about a month's work on and off.
Light on the horizon is still a piece I am unsatisfied with, it went through many stages. The first being just the girl looking out.. and then I added warm lights on the horizon, then the darker clouds.. and lastly came the ship. very experimental painting, about a month on and off.

I started painting about 8 years ago in 10th grade, I always had a love for drawing but my teacher forced me to start painting and I loved it. I just graduated from VCU last year having dual degrees in Art Education and Communication Arts. I am a first year Art teacher and a working painter. I'm doing commissions/shows same time as teaching.

Some of the photos aren't full quality(I'll be taking those tomorrow) but 8x10's are best choice... you can try moving up from there. The higher quality ones will print just fine, see what the file sizes are. Use luster settings instead of glossy

hmmm pictures are NOT the best way to get that mood and correct feeling and capturing of the impression. You want to be able to react to the space from life itself and then after a lot of experience you can use photos as a shortcut. Just be in a space and start. just STARTing is the most important.. and keeping consistency. Before you know you will have developed a method in how you handle materials and process. I paint from life just to stay sharp with observing colors and learning to create a feeling and then use photos that I"VE taken as inspiration to merge the worlds.
They are all for sale! Let me know which ones you might be interested in... They go up tomorrow for the show.

You can keep em. I appreciate the love. Some paintings took a few weeks... paintings like "Beauty, then Reality" took 3-6 months. the NYC piece took many layers as well, probably 2 months.. any particular you want to know?
That's the next portfolio themes after this show is over. thank you for the feedback

haha! I feel I was in love with it while doing it but it is pretty much overpowering the rest of the work. People are always talking about that one and it's a great feeling but some of the work I've spent MONTHS on don't get as much love. I probably did that in a few weeks.
Besides that, the concept holds very dear to me, mans lone journey, both spiritual and real. It represents sometimes the narrow paths we must take as much even though we may be afraid or don't see the end of the path itself.
Thank you! responding asap to those requests!

haha! Thank you, I am honored. I love listening to a lot of different kinds of music. A lot of nujabes...watsky...21 pilots...linkin park....and relaxing dubstep. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E1e3XtQ7D5Q)
Some albums... "All you can do"-watsky "Vessel"-Twenty one pilots "Spiritual state"-nujabes "A Thousand Suns"- Linkin park
That would be so great, thank you!
thank you! I appreciate the kind words

They range from ~$500-~4,000. The 18"x24" are closer to the $500-$600 range and the bigger ones such as the woman in "Beauty, then reality" which is closer t 40"x40" is $4,000. It also depends on the amount of time and layers, I spent 3 months on that one while some may take a night. Any specific one you are interested in? I am finalizing prices atm, so I can get back to you with a better answer.

actually, that's my next subject matter/ theme. I want to walk around the find places that are not so well known and shed some light on them. bball courts, alleyways, certain neighborhoods and the people from them as well as create a contrast of downtown busy life dc

I've posted it incomplete with a few others in an album. To be honest I think its the more weaker of my works. I was criticized last time for the perspective /other formal things. Hi. Yes of course ! I'm in the u.s at the moment so sometimes Its hard to accept universal commissions because of shipping costs etc
Hahahahahahahahahaahhaa you win

I started out with realism and hyper-realism in mind and i don't know, I think my lazyness drifted me into a phase of leaving things unfinished and more expressive. I then started using a palette knife to paint because I didn't want to waste time cleaning brushes, just mixed colors with the paint and also threw it on canvas an moved it around with the knife. It was very efficient and I learned to break down important lines and shapes of value without blending and taking forever on it. I also loved the texture it allowed me to obtain. The brush feels a lot like drawing almost and sometimes doessn't leave too many chances to let the expression and artist's hand show through because you get caught up in refinement. The palette knife is all about the marks/strokes and being in the moment to react to a subject. Sorry, for the short answer, I think yeah, it's a mixture of expressionism(faces) and impressionism(places) and I choose areas to refine in the end to build up the focus in one area such as the eyes or face. I feel like I just threw up in this comment, I'm actually in the studio right now working to finish up pieces late at night. and thanks I'll need the luck for the show! keep stenciling and spraying...safely that is, out in the open

Thank you! Yeah, painting is my passion and life. I teach it full time and also am working to establish myself as a professional artist. I'm actually preparing for my first solo show. heres my portfolio site: www.ramandipsingh.com FB: the art of raman singh and insta: art_of_raman
Thank you and let me know if you have other questions:)
Thanks and yupp, Oil paint. It's all done in palette knife and some parts I smudged around with my fingers too.
